comments.message: Hi Joseph, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. description: If Ebola becomes widespread speed of decontamination might be paramount. The bleach level of the pool would need to be maintained. Since I have ZERO experience with wet suits...tell me what you think.
summary: It seems that decontaminating healthcare workers for Ebola patients is time consuming and sometimes unsuccessful. My idea is this: wet suits (much as surfers or divers wear) would be much less bulky and allow the workers more freedom and ease of movement. The hands and feet would need to be addressed. When the time for decontamination comes there should be a wading pool with an appropriately high level of bleach that would kill Ebola. The workers would first dip their arms in the pool; then climb in and submerge up to neck. After exiting the pool the head would need to be addressed. Someone would need to constantly clean the small stairs to the pool
title: Protecting healthcare workers from Ebola
